history.content:
The prereqs for that class include Ind Eng 162 (which also has Math 53 as a prereq), so probably.

As a grad-level course, you also need to contact the instructor about enrollment policies for undergrads.

children.subject:
170 spends only 2 weeks and not a full semester on that topic, so maybe, but probably not.

Glancing at the most recent syllabus and reading the lecture topics, I would guess that CS170 covers lectures 2-4, 14-15, 21-23, and maybe parts of 5-6. There's been like one recent semester that covered a bit of lecture 17-18 in homework problems, and past semesters used to cover simplex (lectures 8-10) but not really any more. (Also, the way 170 teaches simplex is distinctively non-standard (i.e. if you Google "simplex" and look at any other school or resource like Wikipedia, the terminology and details of implementation are all different, since the 170 textbook only presents a high-level overview). Instead, if you want to learn simplex, I would suggest just trying to code up an implementation of simplex by hand.)

Looking at past midterms on TBP, I would expect 170 students who learned simplex to solve about half to two-thirds of the exam, and 170 students who didn't learn simplex to solve one-third? (Judging from the syllabus, they might do better on the final, but there aren't any recent past finals on TBP.)
Ind Eng 162 is linear programming. I am also taking 170 next semester which covers linear programming and network flows. Would it work as a substitute?

history.content:
I've taken CS 70 and Math 54 and EE 16A. Do I need to take another few classes before 221?

"Introduction to Financial Engineering

A course on financial concepts useful for engineers that will cover, among other topics, those of interest rates, present values, arbitrage, geometric Brownian motion, options pricing, and portfolio optimization. The Black-Scholes option-pricing formula will be derived and studied. Stochastic simulation ideas will be introduced and used to obtain the risk-neutral geometric Brownian motion values for certain types of Asian, barrier, and lookback options. Portfolio optimization problems will be considered both from a mean-variance and from a utility function point of view. Methods for evaluating real options will be presented. The use of mathematical optimization models as a framework for analyzing financial engineering problems will be shown."
history.subject: Prereqs for INDENG 221 (Financial Engineering)?
